DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
CORONAVIRUS UPDATE

WHO's Tedros said COVID-19 is a global pandemic and suggested to double down and be more aggressive to contain the virus, while WHO's Ryan said Iran and Italy are in the front line of COVID-19 but other countries "will be in that situation very soon". (Newswires)

Italy’s coronavirus total cases rose to 12,462 (prev. 10,149) and death toll rose to 827 (Prev. 631). Italy PM Conte said closing all shops aside from groceries and pharmacies for the entire country, while they are closing bars and hairdressers nationwide. PM Conte also stated they are closing all eateries which cannot guarantee 1 metre distance between customers although factories can continue to operate with precautions. (Newswires)

UK coronavirus cases increased to 456 vs. Prev. 373, according to the Health Ministry. (Newswires)

German Chancellor Merkel said experts state that 60-70% of population will be affected by virus, while she suggested we must slow the spread and countries should not isolate each other in Europe. (Newswires)

 

ASIA-PAC

China's Cabinet said they will be making targeted RRR cuts as well as additional cuts to some other banks, and will take measures to stabilise foreign trade and investment according to State Media. (Newswires)

BoJ are likely to ease monetary policy next week to prevent market volatility from affecting business sentiment with increasing ETF buying seen as among the likely options according to sources. However, reports added there was no consensus yet and that the plan is preliminary and subject to change as board are yet to discuss the next steps. (Newswires)

BoJ are to keep purchasing ETFs at the current pace of JPY 100bln in order to continue to support the stock market, at least until March 31st, according to sources. (Newswires)

  • Chinese New Yuan Loans (CNY)(Feb) 905.7B vs. Exp. 1100.0B (Prev. 3340.0B). (Newswires) 
  • China Aggregate Financing (CNY)(Feb) 855.4B vs. Exp. 1586.0B (Prev. 5070.0B)
  • Chinese M2 Money Supply (Feb) Y/Y 8.8% vs. Exp. 8.5% (Prev. 8.4%)

 

UK/EU

BoE delivered an emergency 50bps rate cut to 0.25% from 0.75% via unanimous decision, while it maintained gilt purchase target & UK corporate bond purchases. BoE said is will introduce a new term funding scheme for small businesses, while the FPC have reduced the UK's counter-cyclical buffer to 0.0% vs. Prev. 1.0% which was due to reach 2.0% by December 2020 and will release support of up to GBP 190bln to businesses. Furthermore, BoE will take all further necessary steps to support the UK economy and financial system, consistent with its statutory responsibilities. (Newswires)

UK Chancellor Sunak announced the budget which included a further stimulus injection into the UK economy and a "three point plan" to help combat the impact of the virus which will see the government spend GBP 5bln to support the NHS, GBP 7bln to support the self-employed and businesses and a further GBP 18bln of fiscal loosening to help support the economy in 2020; a grand total of GBP 30bln, while he also announced an increase in infrastructure spending of more than GBP 600bln over the course of the next five years. (Newswires)

Sun's Political Editor tweeted that it sounds like next week's EU trade talks in London will be postponed due to coronavirus and Senior Minister Gove said it's "a live question" and the UK Government has been given "indications" from Brussels that they're unlikely. (Twitter)

European leaders did not unite behind a co-ordinated EU wide fiscal stimulus package, in-spite of requests from France and other states for a massive response. (FT)

  • UK GDP Estimate (Jan) Y/Y 0.6% vs. Exp. 0.9% (Prev. 1.2%). (Newswires)
  • UK Industrial Production (Jan) Y/Y -2.9% vs. Exp. -2.6% (Prev. -1.8%)
  • UK Manufacturing Production (Jan) Y/Y -3.6% vs. Exp. -3.5% (Prev. -2.5%)

 

COMMODITIES 

US EIA Weekly Crude Stocks w/e 7.664M vs. Exp. 2.266M (Prev. 0.785M). (Newswires)

Saudi Aramco received a directive from the Energy Ministry to increase maximum sustainable capacity from 12mln BPD to 13mln BPD, with oil production capacity to be raised to 13mln BPD as soon as possible. (Newswires)

US EIA cut 2020 world oil demand growth by 660k BPD and sees a 0.37mln BPD y/y increase but raised forecast for 2021 world oil demand growth by 210k BPD to 1.73mln BPD. (Newswires)

OPEC Monthly Oil Report lowered 2020 global oil demand growth forecast by 920k BPD from prior report to 60k BPD – reflecting slower global economic growth associated with a wider spread of Covid-19 beyond China. (Newswires)

Russia Deputy Energy Minister Sorokin said OPEC+ could not cut output indefinitely and that OPEC+ asked Russia to cut by an additional 300k BPD but it would be technically challenging, while he added that global oil demand growth could be close to zero this year due to virus. (Newswires)

 

GEOPOLITICS

US House passed resolution to rein in President Trump's ability to wage war on Iran, although a veto from the President is expected. (Newswires)

Two Americans and one Briton were killed when 15 Katyusha rockets landed at Taji military camp in Iraq. (Fox)

 

US 

US President Trump is considering declaring a national disaster to free up funds for coronavirus response according to a source, while other reports stated the White House is favourably disposed toward declaring a national disaster under the Stafford Act, freeing up to USD 40bln in immediate aid, which could be done soon. Furthermore, President Trump initially indicated he will make remarks at probably 2000EDT/0000GMT and will discuss travel restrictions to Europe, as well as a national emergency but later announced he will be addressing the nation at 2100EDT/0100GMT from the Oval Office, while Trump also said we will be making lots of small business loans after a meeting with top banking executives and believes there will be pent-up demand when the outbreak is over in the hopefully not too distant future. (Newswires/Politico)

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said the top priority of the policy response to coronavirus will be to provide relief from small and medium businesses, actively exploring how workers can be reimbursed for lost pay. Furthermore, Mnuchin hopes to come to an initial agreement with congress within the next 48 hours and this will be the first phase of the stimulus but will not include everything, while there were reports that House coronavirus relief package is to be announced today with a floor vote on Thursday according to a House aide. (Newswires)

White House is to discuss new travel restrictions on European countries at Wednesday's meeting, according to sources. (Newswires)

NY Fed increased size of overnight repo operations in which it will offer at least USD 175bln in the o/n repo ops, while it maintained term repo operations at USD 45bln and will offer three one month operations of USD 50bln. (Newswires)

US Senator Sanders reportedly will say he is to stay in the race and looks forward to debating Biden. (CNN)

  • US CPI (Feb) Y/Y 2.3% vs. Exp. 2.2% (Prev. 2.5%)

 

MARKET RECAP

Tuesday lived very much up to the "dead cat bounce" title as risk aversion swept markets, in fact, outright liquidation was seen across equities (which briefly entered an “official” bear market), oil and even gold and bonds amid a declining liquidity backdrop, widening credit spreads and sustained high vol. The virus continues to boil with WHO officially labelling it as a pandemic on Wednesday, and rapid growth rates in countries such as Italy amplify concerns of a delayed, similar outbreak in the US, where officials move closer to ramped fiscal stimulus. The monetary and fiscal powers came together in the UK with the BoE cutting its benchmark rate by 50bps and announcing other liquidity measures, to be followed a few hours later by the UK Budget unveiling fresh fiscal stimulus. Energy sector (XOP, XLE) saw chunky declines on Wednesday, after the dead cat bounce on Tuesday, particularly shale names such as Apache (APA), Noble (NBL) and Occidental (OXY). DXC (DXC) opened higher as entered a USD 5bln asset sale to pay off debt. Boeing (BA) saw some chunky losses as it announced a halt of hiring, with potential for further job cuts later on, additionally it announced it would be planning a full draw-down of its USD 13.8bln loan as a precaution, which could come as early as Friday. Hilton Worldwide (HLT) was offered as it withdrew guidance due to virus uncertainty; other holiday-related stocks suffered too such as casinos (WYNN, LVS, MLCO, CZR), cruise liners (RCL, NCLH, CCL) and airlines (AAL, DAL, UAL, LUV). SPX -4.89% at 2741, NDX -4.37% at 8006, DJI -5.86% at 23,553.

A choppy session for the TPLEX as duration came to somewhat of a roadblock as equities sold off. Despite the returning risk aversion, after Tuesday’s dead-cat bounce, the belly to long-end of the curve failed to catch a bid. Desks noted the likely profit taking after recent sessions of strong flight-to-quality, particularly RP-type selling the long-end, with bonds failing to perform as an equity hedge as positions become overstretched. Note that participants took advantage of the back up in yields at the 10-year Treasury auction, which stopped through the 0.854% WI by 0.5bps, although did see dealers take a larger than average takedown as well as being covered less than average, but nonetheless did provide a short-lived paring of the steepener, before selling re-emerged into the settlement, where the 10-year yield had risen around 6bps to 0.810%, 2s10s +6.5bps, 2s30s +8.5bps. US T-note futures (h0) settled 13 ticks lower at 137-04+.

subject: Newsquawk US Market Wrap - 11th MARCH 2020: Stocks, Bonds, Oil and Gold lower amid flight to cash
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • SNAPSHOT: Equities down, Treasuries down, Crude down, Dollar up
  • REAR VIEW: Equities briefly enter bear market, Saudi to increase production, Firm CPI, Strong 10-year auction after rate back up, Fed ramps up repo-operation
  • COMING UP: Data: EZ Industrial Production, US Initial Jobless Claims, PPI. Events: ECB Rate Decision & Press Conference. Supply: Italy & US

* MARKET WRAP: Tuesday lived very much up to the "dead cat bounce" title as risk aversion swept markets, in fact, outright liquidation was seen across equities (which briefly entered an “official” bear market), oil and even gold and bonds amid a declining liquidity backdrop, widening credit spreads and sustained high vol. The virus continues to boil with WHO officially labelling it as a pandemic on Wednesday, and rapid growth rates in countries such as Italy amplify concerns of a delayed, similar outbreak in the US, where officials move closer to ramped fiscal stimulus. The monetary and fiscal powers came together in the UK with the BoE cutting its benchmark rate by 50bps and announcing other liquidity measures, to be followed a few hours later by the UK Budget unveiling fresh fiscal stimulus. As duration longs have become extended in recent sessions with rates approaching the zero-lower bound, a slew of profit-taking was exhibited on Wednesday. Additionally, the Fed ramped up its repo operations (again), while its o/n operations saw further demand - note that Boeing, Wynn and Hilton announced they would be drawing down their credit lines, while Blackrock advised its companies to draw on theirs, in a further signal of funding demand ramping up amid supply chain difficulties. Oil's Tuesday rally was shortlived as the offer returned amid reports Saudi was poised to ramp up its production, diminishing hopes of a short-term supply agreement. Data continues to sit in the back seat although US CPI (Feb) did print firmer, for what it's worth. Participants now look towards Trump's statement to be made later on Wednesday (20:00 EDT), where he is likely to declare a national emergency and further travel restrictions. On Thursday, the ECB meeting will draw attention with concerns on how much ammo the bank has left to give.

* BOE EMERGENCY RATE CUT: The BoE have become the latest G7 central bank to lower rates, coming to market with an emergency 50bps reduction in the Bank Rate from 0.75% to 0.25%; the MPC were not due to deliver their upcoming policy announcement until March 26th. Note, markets had fully priced in a 25bps cut at the upcoming meeting with a circa 40% probability of a deeper reduction of 50bps. Unsurprisingly, COVID-19 was cited as the main driving force behind the move with the MPC looking "to help UK businesses and households manage through an economic shock that could prove sharp and large, but should be temporary". In terms of other measures, the MPC refrained from expanding gilt or corporate purchases at this stage, potentially, leaning in favour of using them later down the line if required given that room to the downside is particularly limited for rates. Elsewhere, policymakers opted to offer a new term-funding scheme with additional incentives for small and medium-sized enterprises. The scheme will offer four-year funding over the next 12 months and be carried out at a rate at, or very close to the Bank rate. Additionally, the FPC cut the UK's counter-cyclical buffer to 0.0% vs. Prev. 1.0% (was due to reach 2.0% by December 2020) in a move that will release support of up to GBP 190bln to businesses. In terms of the fallout of the decision, the measures will have to be taken in the context of measures unveiled in today's budget. However, ING conclude that given the demand impact on businesses, the rate reduction will likely do little to offset the cashflow damage from COVID-19, as such, targeted measures that help banks keep credit flowing will likely be deemed more relevant. At the follow-up press conference, current Governor Carney was quick to reassure markets that the MPC could lower rates to close to but above the 0% mark, note, incoming-Governor Bailey said last week that the base rate could be lowered to 0.1% if needs be. It remains to be seen whether or not the MPC would come to market with a 15bps reduction, however, given that historically, movements have occurred in 25bps increments, the market might see a further reduction to 0.1% as piecemeal. With this in mind, Pantheon Macro look for rates to remain at current levels until Q2 2021. Therefore, the next move from the Bank could instead be geared more towards gilt and corporate purchases, which could also explain why both were maintained at current levels today.

* WTI (J0) SETTLED USD 1.38 LOWER AT USD 32.98/BBL; BRENT (K0) SETTLED USD 1.43 LOWER AT USD 35.79/BBL: Oil prices again sold off on Wednesday as OPEC taps look set to turn up. Saudi Aramco has received a directive from the Energy Ministry to increase maximum sustainable capacity from 12mln BPD to 13mln BPD, with oil production capacity to be raised to 13mln BPD as soon as possible. This follows Wednesday’s Aramco announcement that it will be supplying customers with 12.3mln BPD starting April 1st – the timeframe for 13mln BPD output is unclear thus far. Furthermore, Saudi Arabia has asked government departments to submit proposals for 20-30% cuts to their budgets, according to sources. This alludes to the Kingdom readying for a longer period of low energy prices to balance its books. Meanwhile, Russia has shown no signs of caving in – the Finance Ministry highlighted that Moscow is better prepared than any other country with oil revenues. That said, Energy Minister Novak stated that dialogue with OPEC will continue and representatives will be present at the March 19th JTC meeting. Later, Russian Deputy Energy Minister Sorokin said OPEC+ could not cut output indefinitely, where OPEC+ asked Russia to cut by an additional 300k BPD but said it would be technically challenging. UAE has also become the latest producer to increase output, with ADNOC stating that they are in a position to supply markets with 4mln BPD in April and will accelerate to 5mln BPD capacity target, brought forward from 2030. In light of recent events, Algeria’s Energy Minister said intense discussion are being held with OPEC and non-OPEC producers to stabilize the market. Elsewhere, the EIA report caused little market reaction, largely confirming the private data release, where crude stocks (bbls) built more than expected at 7.7mln, gasoline drew 5mln and distillates drew 6.4mln, both deeper than expected, whilst crude production dipped by 100k BPD to 13.0mln BPD.

* COVID-19 RESPONSE: The WHO declared the coronavirus as a Pandemic as global cases continue to rise. During the UK budget, UK Chancellor Sunuk announced a USD 7bln coronavirus package to assist with tackling the virus, meanwhile the BoE reduced its CCyB to 0% to free up liquidity while it also announced a new term funding scheme to assist smaller businesses. Across to Europe, Italian PM Conte announced the Government has set aside a total of EUR 25bln to assist the economy, up from the EUR 16bln touted yesterday. For this to go ahead, the Economy Minister will ask the cabinet to increase its 2020 deficit spending to EUR 20bln, with the cabinet to approve on Friday virus measures worth EUR 12bln. The 2020 deficit levels will depend on how much is spent, he says, noting it is premature to make forecasts. To finance the package the Economy Minister stated some measures could be financed via EU funds, taking the pressure off of Italian public accounts. Meanwhile, Conte did not rule out even tighter restrictive measures, following the lock down. Looking ahead, US President Trump is to hold a press briefing at 20:00 ET / 00:00 GMT which will cover economics and health care.

* UK BUDGET: Following the monetary loosening from the BoE earlier in the session, Chancellor Sunak's debut budget provided a further stimulus injection into the UK economy as the nation attempts to insulate itself from the fallout of COVID-19. Chancellor Sunak announced a "three point plan" to help combat the impact of the virus which will see the government spend GBP 5bln to support the NHS, GBP 7bln to support the self-employed and businesses and a further GBP 18bln of fiscal loosening to help support the economy in 2020; a grand total of GBP 30bln. Furthermore, Sunak vowed to do whatever it takes to help support the economy and provide further measures if needed. Ahead of the release, analysts had speculated over whether or not Sunak would abandon the Conservative's fiscal framework, which would have allowed himself more leeway in providing support. However, the Chancellor noted that today's budget will meet current fiscal rules with a review of the framework to be carried out by Autumn. That said, the Chancellor certainly exceeded expectations for fiscal support and also announced an increase in infrastructure spending of more than GBP 600bln over the course of the next five years; an ambition that was aided today by the BoE's decision to lower rates and therefore borrowing costs for the UK. In terms of assessing the impact of the budget on the UK economy, Pantheon Macro notes that the measures today will not prevent UK GDP from "falling sharply" over the next couple of months. However, the consultancy suggests that it will likely improve the chances that the UK economy rebounds in H2. On the borrowing front, today's figures are slightly opaque given that projections are predicated on OBR assumptions that do not factor in the impact of the virus, which, once factored in later down the line will almost inevitably mean that borrowing as a percentage of GDP in 2020/21 will be higher than currently envisaged. As such, a fiscal tightening in 2022/23 will likely be required in order to abide by the current fiscal framework. Overall, Chancellor Sunak appears to have gone above-and-beyond market expectations on the easing front, which, allied with earlier action from the BoE will have assuaged some concerns over the UK's economic readiness to deal with COVID-19, however, with the extent of the virus still unknown, further easing cannot be ruled out at this stage.

* ECB PREVIEW: Surveyed analysts expect the Bank to stand pat on rates this time around, however, market pricing currently assigns a 100% probability of a 10bps reduction to the deposit rate with a further 10bps priced in by September. The meeting takes place against a backdrop of severe economic uncertainty in which the full extent of the COVID-19 outbreak remains unknown. However, containment efforts across the continent have certainly impaired economic activity and as such, heightened calls for stimulus from the Governing Council. It remains to be seen whether the ECB will adopt a wait-and-see approach or unveil supportive measures, which could include rate reductions, expansion of the APP, adjustments to tiering thresholds, sweetening of the terms of existing TLTROs, financing measures for SMEs. Click here for link.

* US CPI: CPI Y/Y rose more than expected at 2.3%, although the pace slowed from the prior 2.5% while the M/M figure maintained a 0.1% increase, above expectations for a flat print. Core CPI for February printed in line with expectations for a 0.2% rise, maintaining January’s pace, while Y/Y picked up to 2.4% from 2.2% and 0.1% above expectations; Pantheon Macroeconomics expect core inflation to slow over the next few months. The consultancy highlights the headline was depressed by a drop in gasoline prices with a bigger drop to come next month. To conclude PM note core inflation was trending solidly ahead of COVID-19, although travel related costs are expected to drop give the fall in air fares from a slump in demand while and oil prices, while the falling cost of distribution of goods will push prices on a variety of items over the upcoming months, although some of the strength in rentals and perhaps health care services will persist.

* BOJ: Multiple source reports hit which initially suggested the Bank is to keep purchasing ETFs at the current pace of JPY 100bln in order to continue to support the stock market, at least until March 31st, which would initially rebuff prior day sources that the figure could be raised. However, later sources stated the BoJ is likely to ease monetary policy next week to prevent market volatility from affecting business sentiment, with increasing ETF purchases seen among the likely options. The sources noted that there is no consensus yet, the plan is preliminary and subject to change as board are yet to discuss the next steps.

* GEOPOLITICS: The situation in Idlib resurfaces today after Turkish President Erdogan stated that the ceasefire agreed with Russia has been violated on the ground. Although the violations are “small” the Turkish President has urged Russia to take measures over the breach of the week-long ceasefire and reiterated that Ankara will respond heavily, with its harshest retaliation yet, if its military observation posts in the region come under attack. Analysts have previously noted that the ceasefire, under which Turkey and Russia also agreed to establish a secure corridor along a key east-west highway in Idlib and hold joint patrols on it as of March 15, seems as fragile as the prior attempts. Furthermore, the Turkish President stated that Turkey will keep the EU border open to migrants until EU keep promises under 2016 deal, comments which arose after Turkey and EU failed to come to an agreement.

* RBA’s DEBELLE: The Deputy Governor noted last night there are scenarios where QE by the Bank would have to be considered, stating that it would consider forward guidance and keeping bond yields low. During his speech he said “If you’re thinking about trying to keep the front end of the risk-free curve low for a period of time then that’s more analogous to an interest-rate reduction”. Debelle also noted it is easier to think about it in terms of price, rather than quantity when asked about potential bond purchases. As the Bank runs out of policy room with its cash rate at 0.5%, 25bps above its lower bound, participants have been expecting some form of QE. The comments on yields and “price rather than quantity” suggests to analysts that QE from the Central Bank could be more focused on Yield Curve Control, similar to the BoJ, instead of large bond buys.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (H0) SETTLED 13 TICKS LOWER AT 137-04+. A choppy session for the TPLEX as duration came to somewhat of a roadblock as equities sold off. Despite the returning risk aversion, after Tuesday’s dead-cat bounce, the belly to long-end of the curve failed to catch a bid. Desks noted the likely profit taking after recent sessions of strong flight-to-quality, particularly RP-type selling the long-end, with bonds failing to perform as an equity hedge as positions become overstretched. Note that participants took advantage of the back up in yields at the 10-year Treasury auction, which stopped through the 0.854% WI by 0.5bps, although did see dealers take a larger than average takedown as well as being covered less than average, but nonetheless did provide a short-lived paring of the steepener, before selling re-emerged into the settlement, where the 10-year yield had risen around 6bps to 0.810%, 2s10s +6.5bps, 2s30s +8.5bps.

* REPO OPERATIONS: NY Fed will offer at least USD 175bln (Prev. 150bln) in the o/n repo operations. NY Fed maintained the term operations at USD 45bln, and announced it will offer three one-month operations of USD 50bln.

* CLOSING LEVELS: SPX -4.89% at 2741, NDX -4.37% at 8006, DJI -5.86% at 23,553. Sectors: Industrials -5.95%, Financials –5.52%, Energy -5.46%, Real Estate -5.44%, Consumer Discretionary -5.36%, Utilities -5.1%, Consumer Staples -4.89%, Materials -4.76%, Technology -4.7%, Communication Svs. -4.33%, Health Care -3.91%.

* STOCKS SPECIFICS: Energy sector (XOP, XLE) saw chunky declines on Wednesday, after the dead cat bounce on Tuesday, particularly shale names such as Apache (APA), Noble (NBL) and Occidental (OXY). DXC (DXC) opened higher as entered a USD 5bln asset sale to pay off debt. Boeing (BA) saw some chunky losses as it announced a halt of hiring, with potential for further job cuts later on, additionally it announced it would be planning a full draw-down of its USD 13.8bln loan as a precaution, which could come as early as Friday. Hilton Worldwide (HLT) was offered as it withdrew guidance due to virus uncertainty; other holiday-related stocks suffered too such as casinos (WYNN, LVS, MLCO, CZR), cruise liners (RCL, NCLH, CCL) and airlines (AAL, DAL, UAL, LUV) – note that previously names most exposed to China saw the brunt of the selling, although now as the virus becomes that of a pandemic, the selling seems less discriminate now. Furthermore, the declining sentiment weighed on financials (WFC, JPM, BAC, C). Conversely, some COVID-19 beneficiaries such as Gilead (GILD) and Zoom Technologies (ZM), although not all were up (CLX, WMT, TGT, VZ). Cloudera (CLDR) traded higher after an impressive earnings report. PepsiCo (PEP) traded lower, albeit less so than the market, following it announcing it is to acquire Rockstar energy drinks for USD 3.85bln. Apple (AAPL) was under pressure by a PT cut at BofA.

* FX WRAP: USD saw a similar story as it continued to rebound from two-year lows as yields continue to reverse, although gains in the greenback were less pronounced than prior days as risk appetite soured with US equities entering into a bear market coincided with haven appreciation. GBP saw a volatile day amid the emergency rate cut and release of the UK budget, GBP saw initial weakness but quickly reversed as the stimulus measures provided by the BOE should be positive for companies given the reduction in CCyB and the introduction of the term funding scheme, although GBP gains reversed course and traded weaker against both the buck and EUR to end the day. EUR was flat against the greenback but firmer against Stirling ahead of the ECB decision tomorrow, which is to be accompanied with a statement from the ECB’s Bank Supervision Arm outlining ways to support the sector, according to sources. Meanwhile, Italy further increased the allocated size of its coronavirus stimulus package to EUR 25bln, with EUR 12bln to be accepted on Friday by the Cabinet. Haven currencies (ex-gold) were bid, with EURCHF back beneath the touted SNB eyed 1.06 figure and USDJPY saw lows of 104.10 in late trade and remained beneath 105 heading into ASIA-PAC trade. Antipodes were mixed, AUD traded lower amid the broader risk appetite while comments from RBA’s Debelle seemed to suggest Yield Curve Control is an option for QE, while NZD traded firmer against the dollar amid firmer electric card retail sales data. EMFX sold off amid the broader risk appetite; RUB & MXN underperformed as oil prices fell further on further reports that Saudi is to increase oil production even further to 13mln BPD and ZAR was hit on continued loadshedding concerns from Eskom.

subject: WTI (J0) settles USD 1.38 lower at USD 32.98/bbl; Brent (K0) settles USD 1.43 lower at USD 35.79/bbl
analysis_details: • Oil prices again sold off on Wednesday as OPEC taps look set to turn up. Saudi Aramco has received a directive from the Energy Ministry to increase maximum sustainable capacity from 12mln BPD to 13mln BPD, with oil production capacity to be raised to 13mln BPD as soon as possible. This follows Wednesday’s Aramco announcement that it will be supplying customers with 12.3mln BPD starting April 1st – the timeframe for 13mln BPD output is unclear thus far. Furthermore, Saudi Arabia has asked government departments to submit proposals for 20-30% cuts to their budgets, according to sources. This alludes to the Kingdom readying for a longer period of low energy prices to balance its books. Meanwhile, Russia has shown no signs of caving in – the Finance Ministry highlighted that Moscow is better prepared than any other country with oil revenues. That said, Energy Minister Novak stated that dialogue with OPEC will continue and representatives will be present at the March 19th JTC meeting. Later, Russian Deputy Energy Minister Sorokin said OPEC+ could not cut output indefinitely, where OPEC+ asked Russia to cut by an additional 300k BPD but said it would be technically challenging. UAE has also become the latest producer to increase output, with ADNOC stating that they are in a position to supply markets with 4mln BPD in April and will accelerate to 5mln BPD capacity target, brought forward from 2030. In light of recent events, Algeria’s Energy Minister said intense discussion are being held with OPEC and non-OPEC producers to stabilize the market. Elsewhere, the EIA report caused little market reaction, largely confirming the private data release, where crude stocks (bbls) built more than expected at 7.7mln, gasoline drew 5mln and distillates drew 6.4mln, both deeper than expected, whilst crude production dipped by 100k BPD to 13.0mln BPD.

Daily FX Wrap: wild Wednesday for Sterling and wider risk sentiment
content:
USD

The Dollar has been largely side-lined given more eye-catching events elsewhere, but the DXY is holding above the 96.000 handle and extending recovery gains in late EU trade to 96.624 vs 95.909 at worst on the premise or proviso that a US fiscal package to combat COVID-19 will be forthcoming at some stage following disappointment that nothing real/tangible emerged yesterday. For the record, US inflation was slightly firmer than expected on a y/y basis in headline and core terms, but did not prompt much in the way of a response, partly as the data coincided with the start of the UK budget and the overriding focus remains on nCoV, contagion and attempts to contain the epidemic/economic fallout. Back to the index, 96.650 represents Fib resistance.

GBP 

The stage was already set for UK markets given a busy midweek session for scheduled events, but the BoE upstaged data and the Budget in many ways by announcing a 50 bp rate cut ahead of the Liffe and FTSE opens. Moreover, the accompanying statement included details of a new TFSME plus a coordinated full point reduction in the CCYB for banks to 0%, while incumbent Governor Carney and his impending replacement Bailey both underlined that the pre-March MPC policy meeting measures were part of a wider multi-pronged strategy designed to counter the adverse impact of the coronavirus concocted with the Treasury. This arguably upped the ante and anticipation for new Chancellor Sunak to open the fiscal spigot, with the Pound rapidly regaining composure ahead of the aforementioned economic indicators and unruffled by flat monthly GDP vs +0.1% forecast accordingly. However, Sunak mainly stuck to the script aside from freezing fuel duties and Cable relinquished 1.2900+ status again more on the Greenback’s revival, while Eur/Gbp remained closer to the base of a circa 0.8840-0.8716 range.

JPY/NZD 

The major outperformers and most resilient to the Buck’s comeback, as the Yen maintained 105.00+ territory on underlying safe-haven grounds and Kiwi managed to keep sight of 0.6300 due to supportive AUD/Nzd flows following RBA warnings about virus knock-on effects that might warrant unconventional policy action and/or reinforcing dovish guidance. 

CHF/CAD/EUR

All mixed vs the Dollar after forging early gains, with the Franc retesting 0.9400, Loonie back under 1.3700 against the backdrop of retreating crude prices and Euro eyeing support around 1.1250 after losing grip of 1.1300 and breaching a decent option expiry at the big figure (1 bn).

SCANDI/EM

Still no sign of the Riksbank rushing to join global peers with stimulus, so the Sek is deriving support and a cushion against bouts of risk aversion in contrast to the Nok and Rub that are also prone if not dependent on the fortunes of oil. Meanwhile, the Try is still vulnerable to a breakdown of relations with the US and Russia over arms and Syria, but did get a fleeting fillip from a smaller than expected Turkish current account gap.

subject: US House Speaker Pelosi and Treasury Secretary Mnuchin spokes this morning on proposals for coronavirus response package
UK Budget (rolling headline): Total fiscal stimulus of GBP 30bln this year. Next multi-spending review will occur in July
content:
Coronavirus 

Total figure for coronavirus measures is GBP 7bln, NHS will receive GBP 5bln in emergency funding; further GBP 18bln of fiscal loosening this year.  

  • Chancellor Sunak says he will do whatever it takes to support the economy, there will be temporary disruption to the economy. Productivity will shrink for a period
  • Anticipates a decrease in consumer spending
  • Effects will be temporary
  • Need to provide security and support for those who cannot work, as well as provide a bridge for businesses
  • Will uitilise fiscal action

Three point plan (for coronavirus): 

  • Provide whatever extra resources the NHS needs; statutory sick pay available for all who are advised to self-isolate as well as making it easier for them to access other benefits;
  • To temporarily remove minimum income floor to universal credit (cost GBP 500mln). Will provide a separate GBP 500mln fund
  • Businesses under 250 in staff will refund cost of up to 14-day sick pay for the virus, will allow firms to defer tax payments and provide temporary loans - will cost GBP 2bln

BoE

  • Response will be closely co-ordinated with the BoE; with reference to the coronavirus

Tax Cuts

  • Remove business rates property tax altogether for smaller firms
  • Widen the business property tax exemption band - Cutting business property tax will cost GBP 1bln

OBR Forecasts: - have downgraded UK productivity and lowered GDP growth. 

OBR GDP

  • 2020: 1.1% vs. Prev. 1.4%
  • 2021: 1.8% vs. Prev. 1.6%
  • 2022: 1.5% vs. Prev. 1.6%
  • 2023: 1.3% vs. Prev. 1.6%

OBR Inflation

  • 2020: 1.4% vs. Prev. 1.9%

OBR Budget/Deficit (% of GDP)

  • 2019/20: 2.1% vs. Restated 2.2%
  • 2020/21: 2.4% vs. Restated 1.8%
  • 2021/22: 2.8% vs. Restated 1.6%
  • 2022/23: 2.5% vs. Restated 1.5%
  • 2023/24: 2.4% vs. Restated 1.3%
  • Note - these forecasts do not take into account the BoE emergency rate move or the coronavirus

Fiscal Forecasts

  • Will be considering the fiscal framework over the coming months; report back in Autumn if changes are necessary (unclear as to whether this refers to a tweak to the Tory parties 3-fiscal rules)
  • Budget meets current fiscal rooms with spare room

Labour Measures

  • Workers national insurance contributions threshold will increased to GBP 9.5k
  • National living wage will reach 2/3 of median earnings by 2024, if possible

Alcohol Names

  • Will be cancelling the planned increase in spirits duty [Diageo (DGE LN) shares are nonreactive to this)]

Energy Names

  • Will, as of April 2022, freeze climate change levy on on electricity and increase it for gas

Housing Names

  • GBP 12bln to construct affordable housing
  • Stampduty surcharge of 2% on home purchases by non-residents from April 2021

Fuel Duty

  • To be frozen for an additional year

Entrepreneurs Relief on Capital Gains Tax

  • Will be partially abolished, exemption will be reduced to GBP 1mln vs. current GBP 10mln.
  • Measure is ineffective and expensive

Will not be cutting corporation tax

Gilt

  • 2020/21 Gilt issuance remit at GBP 156.1bln vs. Exp. GBP 166.6bln (upside in gilts on the back of this)
  • 2020/21 net T-Bill issuance: GBP 0bln vs. Exp. GBP 3.5bln

DMO Issuance Schedule

  • Via Auctions: GBP 51bln in short dated; GBP 34.2bln in medium, GBP 26.3bln in longs and GBP 12.6bln in I/L
  • Via Syndication: GBP 16bln in long-conventionals, GBP 8bln in I/L
  • Short & Medium dated gilt auctions for 2020/21 are to be slightly above the current level

11th March 2020

  • Energy (XOP, XLE) is facing pressure on Wednesday again as oil prices have taken another move lower as Saudi moves to ramp up its oil production.
  • Goldman Sachs has cut its S&P 500 target to 2450 (15% below current levels), cuts 2020 EPS view to USD 157 (-5% Y/Y); says earnings growth will collapse in Q2 and Q3 but rebound in Q4 and 2021, believes the bull market will end "soon".

DOW

  • Apple Inc. (AAPL) (Information Technology/Technology Hardware, Storage & Peripherals) has had its PT cut to USD 320 from 350 (shares last closed 285.34), lowering its earnings estimates and predicting supply constraints to last until April/May. Meanwhile, Nikkei reports that stocks of its iPad are running low in China due to increased demand to facilitate e-learning amid the virus outbreak.
  • Johnson & Johnson (JNJ) (Health Care/Pharmaceuticals) – Janssen announced FDA Breakthrough Therapy Designation for its metastatic non-small cell lung cancer treatment, JNJ-6372.
  • PepsiCo Inc. (PEP) (Consumer Staples/Soft Drinks) is to purchase Rockstar Energy Beverages for USD 3.85bln.

NASDAQ 100

  • Alphabet Inc (GOOGL) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) has told its North American employees to work from home until at least April 10th amid the virus.
  • Micron Technology (MU) (Information Technology/Semiconductors) has sampled the industry’s first universal flash storage multichip package which would boost 5G phone battery life. Meanwhile, KeyBanc’s Weston Twigg says DRAM and NAND supply will remain limited in 2020, citing his updated memory supply model.
  • Regeneron (REGN) (Health Care/Biotechnology) and Sanofi (SAN FP, SNY) plan to study if their FDA approved arthritis drug, kevzara, could be used as a coronavirus treatment, where it known to combat immune disorders that could ease lung damage or respiratory damage, according to WSJ.
  • Tesla Inc (TSLA) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobiles) CEO Musk said the Co is scouting locations in central USA for its Cybertruck Gigafactory. Elsewhere, CNBC reported the Co has lost Jat Dhillon, a seven-year veteran at the Co.

S&P 500

  • AT&T Inc. (T) (Communication Services/Integrated Telecommunication Services) says it hasn’t seen any significant impact to its supply chain from the coronavirus. Elsewhere, Co has approached ex-Hulu CEO Randy Freer and Jason Kilar, Hulu's founder, about becoming the CEO of WarnerMedia, The Information reports.
  • DXC Technology (DXC) (Information Technology/IT Consulting & Other Services) has entered a USD 5bln sale in cash of its US State and Local Heath and Human Services to Veritas Capital, with proceeds used to pay down debt. Co also withdraws guidance for FY22, citing volatile market environment.
  • Eli Lilly & Co. (LLY) (Health Care/Pharmaceuticals) has been upgraded to Conviction Buy from Buy at Goldman Sachs with a USD 169 PT (shares last closed at 141.19), where analyst Terence Flynn sees its growth profile as one of the strongest in large cap biopharma, citing its strong margin expansion, favourable US channel mix, 2.2% dividend yield and little risk of losses of exclusivities.
  • Hilton Worldwide Holdings Inc (HLT) (Consumer Discretionary/Hotels, Resorts & Cruise Lines) has withdrawn its guidance for the full year, citing unknown impact from COVID-19.

OTHER

  • Adidas (ADS GY) (Consumer Discretionary/Textiles, Apparel & Luxury Goods) FY20 (EUR): FY sales at constant current +6% (exp. +6.4%), operating margin 4.2% (exp. 4.9%), proposed dividend EUR 3.85/shr (exp. 3.83/shr). Q4 net sales 5.84bln, net income 167mln, operating profit 245mln. Co has been experiencing material negative impact from the virus outbreak after the first three weeks of 2020. China revenue has been around 80% below the prior year’s levels between Jan 25th (Lunar New Year) and end of Feb. Co has started to see traffic declines with corresponding negative business impact in Japan and South Korea. Majority of Chinese operating factors have not been impacted so far. Extend of spill over into other countries remain largely uncertain.
  • AllianceBernstein (AB) (Financials/Capital Markets) reports February preliminary AUM -2.4% to USD 614bln, decline due to market depreciation, partially offset by total firmwide net inflows into all three distribution channels - Retail, Institutions and Private Wealth.
  • Chesapeake (CHK) (Energy/Oil, Gas & Consumable Fuels) is reportedly considering a 1:50 to 1:200 reverse stock split.
  • Cloudera Inc (CLDR) (Information Technology/Software) Q4 20 (USD): Adj. EPS 0.04 (exp. -0.03), Revenue 212mln (exp. 202mln). FY21 adj. EPS view 0.25-0.29 (exp. 0.01), Revenue 860mln-880mln (exp. 865mln); announces USD 100mln share repurchase programme.
  • Fiat Chrysler (FCAU, FCA IM) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobiles) will temporarily close plants across Italy to reduce the risk of spreading the virus.
  • Nissan (7201 JT) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobiles) said it is to resume output in the Hubei province in China this week; Honda (7267 JT, HMC) said it is gradually restarting output from its Wuhan site on Wednesday.
  • Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co (TSM) (Information Technology/Semiconductors & Semiconductor Equipment) is to begin 5nm chip volume production in April, according to DigiTimes sources, which note the Co has already had its process capacity fully booked by clients.
  • Uber Inc (UBER) (Industrials/Road & Rail) is developing a service for unaccompanied kids, according to The Information. Meanwhile, the Co announced it may suspend accounts of riders/drivers of those who test positive for COVID-19 or who have been exposed to it.

US EIA raises forecast for 2021 world oil demand growth by 210k BPD to 1.73mln BPD; cuts 2020 world oil demand growth by 660k BPD, sees a 0.37mln BPD y/y increase
content:
• U.S. crude oil production will average 13.0mln BPD in 2020, up 0.8mln BPD from 2019 but then fall to 12.7mln BPD in 2021. These estimates are 0.3mln BPD and 1.1mln BPD lower than in the January STEO.
  • Expects monthly U.S. crude oil production to begin declining around May, with production falling from 13.2mln BPD in May to 12.8mln BPD in December 2020
  • Forecasts OPEC crude oil production will average 29.2mln BPD from April  through December 2020, up from an average of 28.7mln BPD in the first quarter of  2020
  • Forecasts OPEC crude oil production will rise to an average of 29.4mln BPD in 2021
  • Click here
analysis_details: Note, the piece states: "As a result of the March 6 OPEC and partners meeting, EIA no longer assumes production management from OPEC members or partner countries that were previously voluntarily reducing production. Previously, EIA assumed OPEC would limit production in 2020 and 2021 to target relatively balanced global oil markets."

OPEC Monthly Oil Market Report (Mar): 2020 global oil demand growth forecast revised down, global oil supply decreased, OPEC production fell
content:
MAIN POINTS

  • 2020 global oil demand growth forecast revised down by 920k BPD from prior report to 60k BPD – reflecting slower global economic growth associated with a wider spread of Covid-19 beyond China
  • Preliminary data indicates that global oil supply in February decreased by 290k BPD to average of 99.75mln BPD, up 780k BPD YY.
  • In February, OPEC crude production fell by 546k BPD MM to average 27.77mln BPD, according to secondary sources. Crude output increased in Iraq, Nigeria, Angola, Congo and UAE whilst production decreased mainly Saudi in and Libya (-647k BPD MM), Iraq and Kuwait.

OPEC

  • Demand for OPEC crude in 2020 was revised down by 1.1 BPD compared to the prior report and stands at 28.2mln BPD, around 1.7mln BPD lower than the 2019 level
  • The share of OPEC crude oil in total global production decreased by 0.5 ppt to 27.8% in February compared with the previous month

NON-OPEC

  • For 2020, the FSU oil supply forecast revised up by 10k BPD to and is expected to grow 70k BPD to 14.44mln BPD

OECD

  • OECD oil demand was revised down by 60k BPD, with most of the downward revisions appearing in 1H20.
  • Considering the latest developments, downward risks currently outweigh any positive indicators and suggest further likely downward revisions in oil demand growth, should the current status persist.
  • OECD total product inventories rose by 38.6mln barrels MM in January to stand at 1.508bln barrels. This was 59.2mln barrels above the same time a year ago, but 8.8mln barrels lower than the latest five-year average.

CORONAVIRUS

  • Based on preliminary and partly estimated data, China’s oil demand started the year at modest growth levels. Oil demand growth in January 2020 posted an increase of 0.16mln BPD compared to January 2019, though this was far below the average monthly growth level in 2019 of 0.36mln BPD

WORLD ECONOMY

  • Following a considerably weaker economic growth for 2H19 in Japan, Euro-zone and in India, the Covid-19 related developments necessitated a further downward revision of the 2020 GDP growth forecast to 2.4% from 3.0% forecast in the previous month. This compares to a 2019 GDP growth estimate of 2.9%.
analysis_details:
• The report does not seem to take into account the Saudi production ramp-up announcement and OSP reductions
  • The report does however give much more credence to the coronavirus outbreak

Newsquawk Ad-Hoc Economic Analysis - PREVIEW: UK Budget due Wednesday March 11th 2020 at 1230GMT/0830ET
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

Ever since gaining a commanding 80-seat majority in the December 2019 election, expectations have mounted over the government opening-up the spending taps to help boost investment post-Brexit. However, the recent outbreak of COVID-19 has shifted the UK fiscal outlook and as such, this week’s update from newly-appointed Chancellor Sunak will likely be geared more towards tackling the fallout of the virus. Note, the budget will be presented on Wednesday alongside a limited set of OBR forecasts, with an additional set of OBR forecasts to be published on Friday.

subject: Newsquawk Daily US Opening News - 11th March 2020
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Sentiment is somewhat mixed, with US futures lagging their European peers who are bolstered by stimulus measures
  • BoE cut rates by 50bp to 0.25%, in a unanimous emergency decision. Cut the counter cyclical buffer and announced a new term funding scheme
  • Italian PM Conte says the Government has set aside a total of EUR 25bln to assist the economy given the coronavirus
  • Saudi Aramco has received a directive from the Energy Ministry to increase maximum sustainable capacity from 12mln BPD to 13mln BPD
  • Former VP Biden has won primaries in Michigan, Idaho, Missouri and Mississippi
  • Looking ahead highlights include US CPI, DoEs, EIA STEO, OPEC Monthly Report, BoE’s Bailey, Supply from the US

BOE EMERGENCY RATE CUT

BoE cut rates to 0.25% from 0.75%, emergency rate cut - decision was unanimous; Maintain gilt purchase target & UK corporate bond purchases. Will introduce a new term funding scheme for small businesses; Term Funding Scheme will, over the next 12 months, offer four-year funding of at least 5% of participants’ stock of real economy lending at interest rates at, or very close to, Bank Rate; experience from the Term Funding Scheme launched in 2016 suggests that the TFSME could provide in excess of £100 billion in term funding. FPC have reduced the UK's counter-cyclical buffer to 0.0% vs. Prev. 1.0% which was due to reach 2.0% by December 2020; will release support of up to GBP 190bln to businesses. Prudential Regulation Authority (PRA) has today set out its supervisory expectation that banks should not increase dividends or other distributions, such as bonuses, in response to these policy actions. BoE will take all further necessary steps to support the UK economy and financial system, consistent with its statutory responsibilities.

-        An emergency decision which caused immediate upside in Bund June’20 futures (as a proxy) as well as downside in Sterling. Note, minutes for this meeting will be released on Friday 13th March at 12:00GMT, and this meeting was taken with Carney at the helm. As a reference point, on March 16th Andrew Bailey will be taking over as Governor and he is due to speak later today at 17:30GMT. This action comes ahead of the first budget of UK PM Johnsons gov’t at approx. 12:30GMT which is expected to provide support to the economy in wake of the coronavirus, and there was some expectation for joint action between the BoE and Treasury to occur. Full Newsquawk preview for the Budget available in the Research Suite.

Press Conference with Governor Carney & Incoming Governor Bailey: Notes that Bailey took part in today’s decisions.

-        Carney: can cut rates to below 0.25% to close to but above the 0% mark, QE and asset purchases are very much part of the toolkit. Fiscal policy is needed to complement monetary policy. Different form of shock to 2008, no reason for this shock to turn into a repeat of 2008

CORONAVIRUS UPDATE

Mainland China reported 24 additional cases of coronavirus and 22 additional deaths on March 10th vs. Prev. 19 additional cases and 17 additional deaths on March 9th, to bring the total number of cases in mainland China to 80778 and death toll at 3158. (Newswires) China's Hubei province said will implement return to work according to different levels of risk in an ordered manner and that key sectors in Wuhan are allowed to return to work including public transport, medical supplies and daily necessities, while it added it will continue to strictly ban people from leaving Wuhan and Hubei. (Newswires)

Tokyo Olympic Games organising executive is to propose a possible postponement to the games, Kyodo. (Kyodo) In contrast to earlier reports from the Games organisers that there were no plans to do so at present.

South Korea reported 242 additional coronavirus cases to bring total to 7555 and 6 additional deaths to increase death toll to 60. Elsewhere, Japan is reportedly planning to declare a state of emergency due to the coronavirus outbreak after the number of domestic cases rose by the largest daily increase of 59 to a total of 1278, while the total death toll was at 19 and there were 427 discharged from hospital on Tuesday. (Yonhap/Kyodo/NHK)

Italy’s total coronavirus cases rose to 10,149 (Prev. 9172) and the death toll increased to 631 from Prev. 463. Italian PM Conte says the Government has set aside a total of EUR 25bln to assist the economy given the coronavirus; Economy Minister will ask to increase 2020 deficit spending to EUR 20bln, cabinet to approve on Friday virus measures worth EUR 12bln. Conte does not rule out taking further restrictive measures. (Newswires)

US cases of coronavirus surpassed 1000 and the director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said some parts of the country are now beyond containment efforts while Michigan Governor Whitmer declared a state of emergency after 2 coronavirus cases were declared in the state. (Newswires/NYT)

US VP Pence said the US is bringing the full resources of Federal government to the virus efforts and that President Trump proposed a stimulus package to Congress which includes payroll tax relief. There were also comments from White House Economic Adviser Kudlow that President Trump would prefer payroll tax 'holiday' to continue through year-end, while he added they are working on economic package details right now and will outline a more detailed package in the near future. (Newswires)

Canadian PM Trudeau is to make announcement about economic support measures against coronavirus today at 0900EDT, according to CBC Chief Political Correspondent Barton. (Twitter)

ASIA-PAC

Asia-Pac stocks were lower as the prior session’s firm rebound on Wall St that was spurred by stimulus hopes, failed to resonate across the region and US equity futures also pulled back after the White House press conference provided very few details regarding economic measures and where President Trump was a no-show, which overshadowed the Democrat Primaries where mainstream candidate and former VP Biden is set for another decisive victory. ASX 200 (-3.6%) and Nikkei 225 (-2.2%) were lower with the former dragged by heavy losses in gold miners and its largest weighted financials sector to finish in bear market territory, while the Japanese benchmark extended its retreat from the 20k level to reach its lowest level since 2018 as USD/JPY slipped back below 105.00. Hang Seng (-0.6%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.9%) were indecisive amid a lack of fresh catalysts and as the PBoC continued to withhold from liquidity operations, while the latest update from mainland China showed a slight pick-up in the number of additional coronavirus cases and related deaths although this was only marginal and in-fitting with the stabilization narrative. Finally, 10yr JGBs traded slightly higher amid weakness in Tokyo stocks and following the swings in T-notes, while the BoJ were also present in the market today for JPY 430bln of JGBs mainly concentrated in the belly.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a daily net neutral position. (Newswires)

PBoC set USD/CNY mid-point at 6.9612 vs. Exp. 6.9529 (Prev. 6.9389)

PBoC says it will continue to work with relevant departments to provide friendlier and more convenient investment environment for foreign investors. (Newswires)

US

Former VP Biden has won primaries in Michigan, Idaho, Missouri and Mississippi, while Biden and Sanders were tied at 33% each in the Washington Democrat Primary after an estimated two-thirds of the vote count, while Twitter reports noted unconfirmed rumours Sanders is to pull out of campaign. (Newswires)

US Treasury is likely to delay April 15th tax filing deadline as part of an effort to mitigate the effects of the coronavirus on US households and businesses. (Newswires/WSJ)

White House plans to meet with tech giants to discuss coronavirus and said that it had sent principles for drug pricing reform to Capitol Hill, while the White House is also likely to pursue Federal aid for shale companies that are hit by the virus and oil shock. (Newswires/Washington)

UK/EU

UK Chancellor Sunak is to signal end of austerity with a jump in borrowing and said the UK will triple average net investment seen over the past 40 years by the end of this Parliament, while other reports noted that the Budget is to boost infrastructure spending by GBP 100bln and public sector net investment is to rise to 3.0% of GDP from 2.2%. (ITV)

UK GDP Estimate MM (Jan) 0.0% vs. Exp. 0.2% (Prev. 0.3%); Estimate YY (Jan) 0.6% vs. Exp. 0.9% (Prev. 1.2%)

EU is gearing up to rebuff UK's demand for a quick decision on market access rights for London, with EU officials warning that the process will drag on until later in the year at a minimum. (FT) This comes after UK Chancellor Sunak urged the EU for rapid process on necessary approvals by a June deadline.

EU source say that the plan is for the Brexit trade negotiations to go ahead next week "at the moment" but suggests that could change, according to Telegraph's Crisp. (Twitter)

ECB President Lagarde reiterates that ECB is looking at all policy tools, particularly relating to super-cheap funding, and has urged EU leaders that action is needed now, Europe risks a 2008-style crisis. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

Sentiment has recovered from the downbeat tone in the APAC regions as futures resurfaced into positive territory following the surprise BoE rate reduction in a bid to cushion the impacts of the virus outbreak. Cash markets also opened higher to the tune of ~2% [Eurostoxx 50 +1.8%] with broad-based gains seen across the board, but with UK’s FTSE choppy and moving from the top gainer to the laggard on Sterling action ahead of the UK budget unveiling later today (Full preview available on the Newsquawk Research Suite). Sectors are mostly in the green with the exception of the energy sector given the decline in prices in the oil complex whilst financials lead the gains. Unsurprisingly, UK banks have received a tailwind from the BoE cut - with Barclays (+1.5%), Lloyds (+2.0%), Standard Chartered (+3.3%) and HSBC (+1.6%) all in firm positive territory. However, analysts at Goldman Sachs see the announcement of the New Term Funding Scheme as a positive for smaller banks and negative for larger banks as it reduces the latter’s potential hedge from mortgage pricing. Elsewhere, Adidas (-6.4%) shares plumbed the depths post-earnings after noting that the virus outbreak had a material negative impact on China revenues – which are expected to be between EUR 0.8-1.0bln below the prior year’s levels. Similarly, Puma (-3.3%) also issued a negative warning regarding virus impacts, as such these cautious comments have brought down the likes of Kering (-0.7%) and Richemont (-1.1%) in sympathy. Other earnings-related movers include Clas Ohlson (-4.4%) and Mediaset (-0.1%). Meanwhile State-side, desks note US democratic candidate Sanders’ poor performance on Super Tuesday is a mild positive for stocks, although Biden could eventually prove to be a headwind to stocks as the market would prefer a second Trump term.

FX

GBP - Not the biggest net mover by any means, but the Pound has been among the liveliest majors following the pre-Liffe, UK Budget and timetabled March MPC policy meeting ½ point rate cut. The emergency action induced all round Sterling weakness akin to the Dollar’s post-50 bp FOMC ease decline last Tuesday, as Cable recoiled from 1.2900+ to sub-1.2850 and Eur/Gbp jumped to circa 0.8840 from just under 0.8800. However, as the BoE statement and subsequent presser underscored the coordinated nature of measures taken, including funding for SMEs and a 1% reduction in counter-cyclical buffers for banks to zero, and fiscal loosening to come from the Chancellor, Cable and the cross retraced all and more of their initial moves while largely if not totalling shrugging off data in the form of January GDP, IP and output plus trade.

NZD/JPY/AUD/EUR/CAD/NOK - All firmer vs the Greenback, as the DXY fades alongside recovering risk sentiment partly due to the lack of anything material from the US in terms of major steps to counter the adverse economic/social impact of COVID-19, not to mention a degree of disappointment that President Trump was conspicuously absent from the official White House event. The Kiwi is currently top G10 performer, albeit consolidating gains on the 0.6300 handle with the aid of favourable Aud/Nzd tailwinds as the Aussie lags in wake of dovish sounding remarks from RBA Assistant Governor Debelle (underlining QE and forward guidance as potential anti-nCoV contagion tools). Aud/Usd is pivoting 0.6500 and the cross is hovering just above 1.0300, both some distance from recent peaks. Elsewhere, the Yen has pared losses between 105.67-104.11 parameters on the aforementioned flagging risk appetite after Tuesday’s part revival as the Japanese Government prepares supplementary budget initiatives, but the Euro has retreated further from Monday’s near 1.1500 highs to straddle 1.1300 awaiting tomorrow’s ECB meet and the bloc’s fiscal response to the coronavirus. Conversely, the Loonie continues to nurse losses around 1.3700 in the run up to Canadian Q4 cap u that is due alongside US CPI, but also eyeing crude prices like the Norwegian Krona and Russian Rouble that are losing momentum due to crude topping out – Eur/Nok back above 10.8500 and Usd/Rub over 71.5000 again.

RBA Deputy Governor Debelle said coronavirus is causing large increase in risk aversion and uncertainty, while he added the global economy will be materially weaker in Q1 and period ahead but also noted lower interest rates will help offset demand shock from virus. Furthermore, Debelle also stated that there are scenarios where QE would have to be considered and that they would also consider forward guidance as well as keeping bond yields low. (Newswires)

FIXED

Another very volatile first half for EU debt, with German bonds lagging initially and BTPs leading the chorus cheering comments from ECB President Largarde promising decisive monetary and fiscal injections to help prevent COVID-19 turning into a repeat of the GFC. However, Gilts grabbed the spotlight on their return to Liffe and adopted a defensive position post-BoE rate cut and SME lending scheme, awaiting a big budget splurge from 12.30GMT. Conversely, US Treasuries have held a firm underlying bid for the most part overnight and still erring towards risk sentiment souring after a let down in terms of specifics and a final roll out of US Government ‘steps’ to cushion the nCoV blow. In terms of tops and bottoms, Bunds have been up to 177.91 and down to 176.55 vs Tuesday’s 177.59 close, Gilts 137.57-136.82 vs 137.95, 10 year USTs 138-19-137-07 vs 137-20 and BTPs 144.88-142.74 vs 142.60.

COMMODITIES

Another wild ride so far in the energy complex with WTI and Brent front month-futures sliding from overnight highs in wake of further supply prospects and the readying from major oil producers for a prolonged period of low energy prices. Saudi Aramco has received a directive from the Energy Ministry to increase maximum sustainable capacity from 12mln BPD to 13mln BPD, with oil production capacity to be raised to 13mln BPD as soon as possible. This follows yesterday’s Aramco announcement that it will be supplying customers with 12.3mln BPD starting April 1st – the timeframe for 13mln BPD output is unclear thus far. Furthermore, Saudi Arabia has asked government departments to submit proposals for 20-30% cuts to their budgets, according to sources. This alludes to the Kingdom readying for a longer period of low energy prices to balance its books. Meanwhile, Russia has shown no signs of caving in – the Finance Ministry highlighted that Moscow is better prepared than any other country with oil revenues. That said, Energy Minister Novak stated that dialogue with OPEC will continue and representatives will be present at the March 19th JTC meeting. UAE has also become the latest producer to increase output, with ADNOC stating that they are in a position to supply markets with 4mln BPD in April and will accelerate to 5mln BPD capacity target, brought forward from 2030. As mentioned above, the contracts have wiped up overnight gains with WTI Apr’20 slipping from USD 36.28/bbl to a current low of ~USD 33.08/bbl whilst Brent Apr’20 similarly declined from a high of USD 39.60 to a low of ~USD 35.73/bbl. Subsequently, UBS lowered its Brent price forecast for end-June to USD 30/bbl vs. Prev. USD 40/bbl & WTI to USD 28/bbl vs. Prev. USD 37/bbl. Elsewhere, spot gold retains an underlying bit given the weaker Buck, with the yellow metal drifting further north of USD 1650/oz. Copper prices meanwhile remain within yesterday’s range and above USD 2.5/lb as the red metal bides time for fresh macro news-flow.

ANALYSIS: BoE Emergency Rate Cut
content: The BoE have become the latest G7 central bank to lower rates, coming to market with an emergency 50bps reduction in the Bank Rate from 0.75% to 0.25%; the MPC were not due to deliver their upcoming policy announcement until March 26th. Note, markets had fully priced in a 25bps cut at the upcoming meeting with a circa 40% probability of a deeper reduction of 50bps. Unsurprisingly, COVID-19 was cited as the main driving force behind the move with the MPC looking "to help UK businesses and households manage through an economic shock that could prove sharp and large, but should be temporary". In terms of other measures, the MPC refrained from expanding gilt or corporate purchases at this stage, potentially, leaning in favour of using them later down the line if required given that room to the downside is particularly limited for rates. Elsewhere, policymakers opted to offer a new term-funding scheme with additional incentives for small and medium-sized enterprises. The scheme will offer four-year funding over the next 12 months and be carried out at a rate at, or very close to the Bank rate. Additionally, the FPC cut the UK's counter-cyclical buffer to 0.0% vs. Prev. 1.0% (was due to reach 2.0% by December 2020) in a move that will release support of up to GBP 190bln to businesses. In terms of the fallout of the decision, the measures will have to be taken in the context of measures unveiled in today's budget. However, ING conclude that given the demand impact on businesses, the rate reduction will likely do little to offset the cashflow damage from COVID-19, as such, targeted measures that help banks keep credit flowing will likely be deemed more relevant. Looking ahead, from a rate perspective, incoming-Governor Bailey said last week that the base rate could be lowered to 0.1% if needs be. It remains to be seen whether or not the MPC would come to market with a 15bps reduction, however, given that historically, movements have occurred in 25bps increments, the market might see a further reduction to 0.1% as piecemeal. With this in mind, Pantheon Macro look for rates to remain at current levels until Q2 2021. Therefore, the next move from the Bank could instead be geared more towards gilt and corporate purchases, which could also explain why both were maintained at current levels today.

content: The core Eurozone bond was idling rather aimlessly into the EU stock opens when headlines hit heralding another off-schedule Central Bank rate cut, and this time from the UK’s MPC that also unveiled a new funding scheme alongside the FPC removing its 1% counter-cyclical capital buffer for domestic banks. With no Gilts or Short Sterling contracts available to trade, core counterparts rallied by proxy, though only briefly in the case of Bunds and Euribor just a day before the ECB gets its say assuming no like-for-like Fed and now BoE emergency policy action. Indeed, the 10 year German debt future has already unwound knee-jerk gains to a new 177.91 Eurex high vs Tuesday’s 177.59 close and a 176.87 overnight low ahead of Eur4 bn 2030 supply.

ASIA

Asia-Pac stocks were lower as the prior session’s firm rebound on Wall St that was spurred by stimulus hopes, failed to resonate across the region and US equity futures also pulled back after the White House press conference provided very few details regarding economic measures and where President Trump was a no-show, which overshadowed the Democrat Primaries where mainstream candidate and former VP Biden is set for another decisive victory in the Presidential nomination race.
